content: As of 2024-03-28, OpenAI's Text-to-Speech API supports the following languages:

Afrikaans, Arabic, Armenian, Azerbaijani, Belarusian, Bosnian, Bulgarian, Catalan, Chinese, Croatian, Czech, Danish, Dutch, English, Estonian, Finnish, French, Galician, German, Greek, Hebrew, Hindi, Hungarian, Icelandic, Indonesian, Italian, Japanese, Kannada, Kazakh, Korean, Latvian, Lithuanian, Macedonian, Malay, Marathi, Maori, Nepali, Norwegian, Persian, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Russian, Serbian, Slovak, Slovenian, Spanish, Swahili, Swedish, Tagalog, Tamil, Thai, Turkish, Ukrainian, Urdu, Vietnamese, and Welsh.
https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/text-to-speech
As far as I know, there's no comprehensive list of languages supported by OpenAI's GPT models.
One of the responses from ChatGPT contained this expression: low-resource languages such as Latvian, Welsh, and Swahili​
Imagining a mind of an AI that doesnt have any "native language" and should be understanding any languages as arrays of tokens,
I can almost certainly assume their models' language proficiency levels vary significantly between languages
and it's just very hard for them to say which languages can be said to be "supported".
So, it shouldnt hurt to start with the list that's officially available while NOT limiting the languages to the values of this enum.
The reason why we still need this enum is to increase the accuracy of statistical/knowledge analysis.
Language names are often used for dictionary keys, data categories, etc.
We dont want any language to be expressed in multiple ways and act like different ones.
I asked the AI 3 times for more:
I'm tempted to add these "just in case", but I'll keep the list simple and stupid and focus on the major languages for now.
Bengali - Spoken by over 230 million people, primarily in Bangladesh and the Indian states of West Bengal and Tripura, making it one of the most spoken languages in the world.
Punjabi - With over 125 million speakers, Punjabi is the 10th most spoken language worldwide, predominantly in the Punjab region of Pakistan and India.
Javanese - As the primary language of the Java Island in Indonesia, Javanese has around 82 million speakers, making it the most spoken Austronesian language after Indonesian.
Telugu - A language predominantly spoken in the Indian states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, with about 81 million speakers.
Gujarati - Spoken by approximately 56 million people, mainly in the Indian state of Gujarat.
Tamil - Although Tamil is on your list, it's worth noting its significant number of speakers, over 75 million, mainly in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu and in Sri Lanka, Singapore, and Malaysia.
Burmese - The official language of Myanmar (Burma), with about 33 million speakers.
Amharic - As the official language of Ethiopia, Amharic is spoken by about 32 million native speakers and 25 million second-language speakers.
Oromo - Spoken in the Horn of Africa, particularly in Ethiopia and parts of Kenya, with about 37 million speakers.
Pashto - With approximately 50 million speakers, Pashto is primarily spoken in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
Sindhi - Spoken by about 25 million people, mainly in Pakistan and India.
Hausa - A major African language, spoken by about 70 million people, predominantly in Nigeria and Niger.
Malayalam - Spoken by about 38 million people, mainly in the Indian state of Kerala and the union territories of Lakshadweep and Puducherry.
Kurdish - A language group that includes several dialects, spoken by Kurds in Iraq, Turkey, Iran, Syria, and a diaspora worldwide, with around 20-30 million speakers.
Yoruba - A language spoken by about 40 million people, predominantly in Nigeria and neighboring countries.
Igbo - Spoken by around 30 million people, mainly in Nigeria.
Zulu - One of South Africa's 11 official languages, with about 12 million speakers.
Xhosa - Another major South African language, spoken by approximately 19 million people.
Sinhala - The native language of the Sinhalese people, who make up the largest ethnic group in Sri Lanka, with about 17 million speakers.
Cebuano - A language spoken in the Philippines, particularly in the Central Visayas region, with around 21 million speakers.

Farsi (Dari) - While Persian (Farsi) was listed, it's important to highlight Dari, one of the two official languages of Afghanistan, also considered a dialect of Persian, with about 15 million speakers.
Uzbek - The official language of Uzbekistan, with about 32 million speakers.
Tigrinya - Spoken in Eritrea and northern Ethiopia, with around 7 million speakers.
Somali - The official language of Somalia, with about 15 million speakers.
Lao - The official language of Laos, with about 7 million speakers.
Khmer - The official language of Cambodia, with around 16 million speakers.
Turkmen - The official language of Turkmenistan, with around 7 million speakers.
Quechua - A native South American language spoken primarily in Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador, and surrounding countries, with several million speakers.
Aymara - Another important indigenous language of the Andean region, spoken by the Aymara people in Bolivia, Peru, and Chile.
Tibetan - Spoken by the Tibetan people in Tibet, China, and by diaspora communities, it has several dialects.
Mongolian - The official language of Mongolia, and also spoken in some regions of China.
Kyrgyz - The national language of Kyrgyzstan, with about 4 million speakers.
Tajik - A variety of Persian spoken in Tajikistan and parts of Uzbekistan and Russia.
Sinhalese - The majority language of Sri Lanka, distinct from Tamil which is also spoken there.
Kazakh - Although already listed, it's significant to note its role as the state language of Kazakhstan.
Dzongkha - The national language of Bhutan.
Bambara - Spoken in Mali, it's the mother tongue of the Bambara ethnic group and a lingua franca in the country.
Kinyarwanda - The official language of Rwanda, spoken by virtually all Rwandans.
Kirundi - Closely related to Kinyarwanda, it's the official language of Burundi.
Luxembourgish - The national language of Luxembourg, alongside French and German.
Greenlandic (Kalaallisut) - The main language of Greenland, an autonomous territory within the Kingdom of Denmark.
Bislama - A creole language that serves as a lingua franca in Vanuatu, blending elements from English and indigenous languages.
